In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. An obvious workaround for longer recordings was to release a set of records. However, asymmetry of causation can be observed in a non-arbitrary way which is not metaphysical in the case of a human hand dropping a cup of water which smashes into fragments on a hard floor, spilling the liquid. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The causes of the resultant structure and shape of the cup and the encapsulation of the water by the hand within the cup are not easily attributable, as neither hand nor floor can achieve such formations of the cup or water. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. South Korea: The event was held in Seoul, which hosted the 1988 Summer Olympics, on April 27. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. More than 8,000 riot police were deployed to guard the 24-kilometre route, which began at Olympic Park, which was built when Seoul hosted the 1988 Summer Games. On the day of the torch relay in Seoul, Chinese students clashed with protesters, throwing rocks, bottles, and punches. A North Korean defector whose brother defected to China but was captured and executed by the DPRK, attempted to set himself on fire in protest of China's treatment of North Korean refugees. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. An adolescent 's environment plays a huge role in their identity development . While most adolescent studies are conducted on white , middle class children , studies show that the identity formation of minority adolescents is complex and affected by unique pressures . One example is the pressure of fitting in and adapting to two different environments as an adolescent . Another example is the pressure of making identity choices that have cultural relev ance . Using a narrative method , this research explores a Latina adolescent 's life course and how she copes with these types of pressures . The narrative will explore her cultural background s , her relationships with her parents and friends , the culture s of her two schools , and how she adapts to her roles and press ur es as an adolescent . The data collected will be analyzed by examining both the text and the participants reactions to the prompts . Compared to other team sports , the National Football League preseason is very structured . Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year , two at home and two away ; each game lasts of exactly five quarters , and each has a defined clock limit ( 2 : 55 minutes for full-length games ) . Thus , 28 of the total 40 regular season team games each year are conducted on the exhibition pre- season ( the other 12 regular season games take the form of half-length games ) . In addition , of the four pre-season exhibition games , two are played outside the regular NFL regular season window ( August and September ) during the NFL preseason regular season window ( July and August ) , one is hosted by an NFL team within its home state ( called the `` home `` game ) , while the other is hosted by an NFL team out of state ( called the `` away `` game ) . In practice , not all rule violations will result in a disqualification as the referee may use their own judgement and is not obligated to stop the match . In , some rules are allowed to be “ pushed ” by the referees . If the ref erees think it is within a certain range of fair play , they will allow it . This is where the “ Spirit of the Game ” differs from actual rules . Many rules that could be viewed as viol ations , are pushed by referees to maintain the spirit of the game . A violation of spirit or “ unsports manlike conduct ” will not result in a disqualification . They are also much less likely to result in a point being taken away or a time fault .

To extend and consolidate the dynasty 's control in Central Asia , the Kangxi Emperor personally led a series of military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia . The Kangxi Emperor was one of the most enlightened and capable of a long succession of great Han Chinese male rulers in the history of the empire . He was of a generation of rulers whose political education had been based on a thorough knowledge of Confucian classic texts . As a result , he displayed a confidence in the imperial government ( which had been the hallmark of ruling dynasties ) that could only be the result of the personal application of a thorough study of the classic texts in combination with the political and military experience that previous rulers had gained in practice . This was an ideal combination of Confucian scholars and the imperial house . From the 1970s onward , Stuart Hall 's pioneering work , along with that of his colleagues Paul Willis , Dick Hebdige , Tony Jefferson , and Angela McRobbie , among others , introduced new ways of thinking about the social and cultural significance of popular culture . His seminal text Popular Culture : An Introduction ( edited with Tony Jefferson and Bob White ; Methuen , 1978 ) established 'sociology of culture ' as a major area of study in its own right , and its influence continues to the present . Hall was a major and enduring figure in English-speaking sociology and cultural studies , combining a range of theoretical perspectives and methods to produce an original , stim -ulating , and compelling body of work . In terms of his writing , his texts are typically characterised by clarity of analysis and a stylish , readable prose , marked by an attention to the linguistic conventions , aesthetics , and politics of popular cultural discourse . Mammalian hair , also known as pelage , can vary in color between populations , organisms within a population , and even on the individual organism . Light-dark color variation can be due to different melanin ( a dark pigment ) concentrations in hair . The most common explanation for this variation is the influence of evolution by natural selection . The color variation can be a key trait in species recognition , with darker-color ation being perceived as more dominant , healthy , or more threatening . The variation can also be linked to factors such as the geographic location or time of year . Social factors have also been linked to color variation since some members of a population will become lighter or darker as a result of their social status . < /s > Another factor which impacts color variation is sexual selection ; lighter colors may indicate youth , lower resource requirements , and are often a means of court ial display . They review the history of the application of F ST to these sorts of questions , and the reasons it has often been found to be uninformative . They also give some reasons for their own skepticism , while being careful to point out that at least some of the difficulties they point to are avoidable . They also note that some other ways of partitioning human diversity can be more informative . They have a large b ibliography , which serves as an introduction to the paper . Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism , in particular Kant 's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond finite inclinations , impulses etc . Thus Hegel attempts to answer the question , how does ethical objectivity get incorporated into subjectivity ? ; i.e . how is the ethical object , the good , made an element in the subjective ? That is the question to do with the subject-object relationship . The second , and most problematic , question is , How does morality relate to morality ? As a result , Hegel is driven to formulate his conception of a concept or idea in the most general way possible . But in order to do this , he needs to begin , paradoxically , by explaining how subjective content can get generalized so that it will be the source of objectivity . Strict separation of powers did not operate in The United Kingdom , the political structure of which served in most instances [ citation needed ] as a model for the U.S . '' Constitution . The relationship between the executive and the legislative components of power also was characterized by a degree of flexibility , allowing the monarch and Parliament to exercise executive authority without disregarding the requirements of the law . Throughout the 14th century , French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility . They ran into difficulties when attempting to conscript nobles into military service , which was an important matter in wartime , but a less urgent matter in peac etime . As a result , the king had to entice the nobles into becoming participants in campaigns – a much less ardu ous task – in order to raise armies . In search of ways to gain noble cooperation , which would include the loaning of arms and men , the king turned to the feudal practice of offering lands as a reward for services rendered - the creation of fiefs and the institution of fe udalism . This created a two -tier society : the knight ly class and their followers , along with the aristocrat class . The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood ; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals . As a result , the difference in concentration between the lung air and blood is less than in mammals , requiring a much less oxygen . The down fe athery covering of the respiratory system of birds actas a low density insulating air blanket . Birds are able to have such dense lungs because they are not constantly used for gase exchange . Instead of taking in oxygen for energy , and using oxygen as the end product of cell metabolism , birds convert food into a volatile chemical called pyruvate . This chemical is then passed from the digestive tract to the lungs where it is converted to carbon dioxide . Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle . For most , the search for identity begins in the adolescent years . During these years , adolescents are at an age when they gain more independence from parents . The adolescent years are very important because te hse years help one gain more knowledge and develop into a proper functioning adult . The developmental tasks of identity must be accomplished in these years , while the e ect of a weak family or parents who are emotionally or physically available can have a detrimental e ect on one ’ s identity development . In addition , identity issues begin to emerge during these years . The term identity is used in many ways and is usually related either to adulthood in general or to a person ’ s self-perceptions about one ’ s social role and how he / she is perceived by others . It refers to one ’ s sense of who one is and one ’ s perception s as to what

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance . Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-concept , identity represents a coherent and integrated system of mental representations that helps to establish a sense of consistency of self -attributes . The self- aspect of identity refers to attributes or dimensions of self that are viewed as personal , stable , and unique . The ego aspect of identity is viewed as concerned with “ how one looks , speaks or behaves in the real world in reference to how one would be known or judged by others ” ( Marcia & Elkind , 196 4 ) . As an individual moves from adolescence into adulthood , the self- aspects are increasingly identified with the ego aspects of identity . Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician , Gregorio Marañón , who injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt . Before injecting the medication , physicians would inform some patients of the medication to be administered and other patients that they were being treated in exactly the same way , but not exactly what medicine was being administer . While all participants reported effects following the injection , only those who thought they had received epinephr ine reported a negative response ( Marañón , 19 29 ) . While one could attribute this response to the power of suggestion , one could equally attribute it to the fact that people respond to stimuli based on their expectations . Thus , how one feels about a stimulus ( such as the medication ) will influence what one expects about the stimulus and therefore alter the effects . The deeper ancestral demography of Bermuda 's population has been obscured by the ethnic homogenisation of the last four centuries . There is effectively no ethnic distinction between black and white , and no distinct white or black Bermudians - a unique situation compared to other Carib bean islands where people would often be described as black or white based on the historical colonial dominance in the region of the particular colonising power Bermuda is part of . With only about 76 , people of African descent remaining in Bermuda , the island is one of the few places in the world that retains a pure , living African population . Like the reptiles , birds are primarily uricotelic , that is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or other nitrogen -containing comp ounds . Uric acid is insoluble in water , so birds excrete it unchanged in the form of a paste or as white flakes that can easily be seen in the dropping of house sparrow , house finch , starling , and other backyard birds . The shape of a bird ' s droppings can help you identify the species , especially if you know the shape of the dropp lings of one or more species . You can learn to identify a species by the shape of the droppings it leaves . Bird droppings have no odor . Droppings from raptors also appear to have a lighter color than dro ppings from corv ids . The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo , signed on February 2 , 1848 , by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary representatives Luis G. Cuevas , Bernardo Couto , and José Domingo Umaran , concluded the war of Mexican independence , known since independence as the Opium Wars or the Mexican-American War . The treaty effectively ended the Mexican war , establishing the territorial boundaries of the United States , Mexico , and California . In exchange for the acquisition of the ceded territory , the United States paid Mexico $ 15 million , agreed to assume Mexican debts to US citizens , and settled the claims of Mexican citizens against Americans . The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was signed by Mexican representative Umar an and American diplomat Trist , but it needed the appro val of the Mexican cabinet and the US Senate . The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate , as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons . The ceremonial process ions and orations , and the sovereign ’ s role in formal government proceedings , are in part symbolic and historical , but also reflect how our country ’ s Constitution came to be written . The Oath of Alleg iance also continues the traditions of the earlier monarchical ceremon ials , but it is now administered by the Privy Council and not the monarch . The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem hold that the majority one 's feelings about themselves comes from the feedback they get from other people . If others feel a person is unworth while others are happy to criticize the person and he or she accepts it , then one 's self -esteem would be low . Also other 's reaction to one might make one 's self - esteem low by comparison . However , if others are happy to praise the person and the person accepts it , then one 's self -esteem is high . Some other theories hold that self- esteem might come from the person them self as well as others . Some theorists believe that the way a person was treated before would affect one 's self- esteem . When John 's elder brother Richard became king in September 1189 , he had already declared his intention of joining the Third Crusade . Richard set about raising the huge army needed for the long journey and the siege of the Holy Land , but before he could leave for a second time for the East , on 19 February 119 1 he had first to go through the process of coronation in London . By coincidence , he then visited the capital of Wessex , Winchester , once the medieval seat of the ancient kings of Wessex . Here he stopped at the house of Bury St Edmund , the abbey of St Peter . After leaving Winchester , the army , now in the east of the kingdom , turned back and made its way north wards across the county of Suffolk . When it reached Bury , the party halted at what is now called Char lton , a place well known to medieval Christians as B ury St Edmund .

Following the fall of Wu and the turmoil of the Wu Hu uprising against the Jin dynasty ( 265–420 ) , most of elite Chinese families had collaborated with the Jin royal family in fighting against the Wu rulers . As the late Jin dynasty ended , these high -ranking families lost much of their status and influence within China . These families fled with the Jin royal family in hopes of seeking safety and protection in far - off countries away from China . Many of these families first migrated to Mongolia and Central Asia , before settling in China proper again as they re - established the Sui andTang dynasty . Another group of families , however , decided to continue living and working in the various countries where they had settled . Most commonly , these were descendents of government official that migrated from cities and provinces in the east to the country states in the west . A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels ( e.g. , anger , pride , fear , guilt , love , and so on ) . In our research on emotion , we concentrate on an approach to the analysis of emotions that builds on the idea of emotional schemes . Emotional schemes are concepts that represent the socially shared characteristics that people associate with each other , and these schemes can be expressed in either ver bal or nonver bal language ( e .g . emotional labels , facial expressions , gestures , and body pos t ures ) . An emotion scheme may contain several emotional labels that are associated with similar or related sets of characteristics . The United States has become essentially a two-party system . Since a conservative ( such as the Republican Party ) and liberal ( such as the Democratic Party ) party each dominates the system , other parties are not likely to gain sufficient influence or be able to affect government policy . A two- party system occurs when voters consistently choose one of the two major parties , and when one of the two major parties usually domin ates the legislative chamber . For example , only a majority of Americans support a presidential candidate , and therefore the presidential election is a contest between two rival parties . The winner is likely to get a plurality of votes , or the same number or a plurality more than . The two- party system is the norm for most dem oc ratic countries . The United States is an exception . Some researchers see the two-party system as a weak form of democracy , as it discourages public participation and participation by independent candidates or

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages : natural philosophy , logic , medicine , theology , mathematics , astronomy ( and astrology ) . In 14 57 , William Lily published ' Ari osto ' , an important reference to the art of teaching . In the 18th century , universities began to focus on subjects such as law , medicine , philosophy , science , theology , statistics , and the arts , which were studied for religious or political reasons . The two major types of nonprofit organization are membership and board-only . A membership organization elects the board and has regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws . Membership organizations can use membership dues as a way to raise money . The members have the power to enforce accountability of the nonprofit board members as well as the right to recall board members . A nonprofit board is normally a group of individuals appointed by nonprofit organizations to manage the administration and operation of a nonprofit . They are a critical part of the running of any nonprofit organization and can play a critical role not only in the daily functioning of the organization but can also help to achieve the mission of the nonprofit . The three stages of development of nonprofit organizations are pre- emergence , emer gence , and m ature . Nonprofit organizations typically operate on a tight budget . Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent 's life . For example , menarche ( the first menstrual period of a new girl ) and the end of puberty represent the beginning and the end of one phase in the life of an adolescent . Menarche is a biological landmark , and the end of puberty is a psychological one . If we were to take our car as an example , we might say that a mature adolescent is now the equivalent of an owner of a sports car who has recently passed an obstacle test and received a driving license ( a biological milestone ) and is now allowed to drive a car ( a social one ) . The driving and the driving test , however , are not milestones in themselves but are the result of passing an obstacle test . The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire . Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as `` invasions '' , the conquest of the Western Roman Empire was not a violent or bloody affair . The emp ire had been in decline for more than a century before Germany conquered the western Roman Empire . The Western Roman Empire was also in decline due to the plague and attacks by German ic raiders . The West of the Empire had already been conquered by German raiders before A.D . 800 . So the German ra iders were not conqu ering a completely peace able world ; they were conquering a people weakened by war and plague . It was the Germanic people who eventually settled the lands lost to the Romans that took the name Germani — those who became the English , the French , the Danes , the Germans , and the Dutch . Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from a patient is initially added onto the agar and inc ubated . Many bacterial colonies have distinctive morphology on culture , and can be used to easily distinguish the causative agent of an infection . Culture has been the foundation of clinical microbiology laboratory diagnostics , but the need for rapid diagnostic results has challenged culture methods for use in the clinical setting . PCR involves the application of a probe on a suspect DNA that will fluoresce if the match to a specific sequence occurs . PCR is highly sensitive and can detect as few as one viral molecule and single bacteria . Many bacteria can be detected with PCR within 24 hours , while viruses and parasites show the same potential in two days . PCR is an excellent technique . While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned , Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture . Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive from pagan customs that had become institutional ized by the Church over the centuries . While a full description of the various fest ivities would take more time than our editors are willing to make available , three Carnival customs deserve special mention at this time . As early as the Middle Ages , masking was associated with Carnival . The custom was rev ol uted in the beginning but was gradually tolerated by the Church , so long as it did not devolve into licentiousness . Eventually the custom evolved into a public ceremony , in part because the mask disgu ised the wearer from his fellow town spers on . Adolescence marks a rapid change in one 's role within a family . Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully , but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family decisions . Ad olescents , in contrast , are able to participate fairly directly in the social life of the family , as members of the extended family and friends also take a growing interest . This emerging sense of family responsibilities , together with other adolescent preoccupations , leads to a sense of family as an organ i sation . The family serves a number of different functions for the adolescent , providing nurturance , guidance , and a sense of identity . This article traces the development of adolescent roles within their families across different cultures .The family environment during adolescence is a primary influence on adolescent behaviour and identity . It also provides a context in which adolescents develop an independence from parents and an increased sense of self , often in tension with the continued desire for parental approval and

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period , plenty of sunshine , and a moderate rainfall , usually from 600 to 1,200 mm ( 24 to 47 in ) . If the fro sts are severe or early , a cotton crop can not be planted ; if they are mild and come after the crop has produced its fruits , then this causes the fruit to drop or causes the remaining ones to rot . Cotton requires a long period of growth and its cultivation can suffer if the winter is too hot ( in Australia ) , or if winter days are short ( as is the case in parts of Pakistan and Uzbekistan ) . Cotton tolerates hot winds and drought quite tolerably , but too much rainfall for a prolonged period causes the plants to rot . < eos > The length of period required to grow cotton varies with the seed used . Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker that is associated with a group that the other person does not share . This exclusion occurs because the marker is defined in terms of a group with boundaries that do not permit outsiders . Inclusion , in contrast , comes from the recognition of the other person as a member of one 's own group . For example , children can be asked whether the children from a neighboring school are their classmates . The possibility of classifying people as not belonging to their own group would viol a¬tion people 's desire for inclusive boundaries that would enable them to maintain their sense of belonging within the group . Ex clusion is therefore a violation of social rules and is likely to be disappro ving , whereas inclusion is not a violation for the other person . B oundaries that are based on inclusive membership

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( NS ) of the supply line between the stations . For the NS to function it is necessary that the Neutral Section is supplied from two adjacent main bus sections . Therefore in the distribution grid there needs to be a supply of two adjacent feeders to a section ( and the reverse ) . This is called ‘ feeding a section of line ’ . The feeders are numbered consec ration to the feed the section of line . In the event of a failure of a feeder in the distribution grid , the NS provides isolation between two adjacent feeders and the remaining feed to the section ( as a load ) ensures safe operation . The relationships adolescents have with their peers , family , and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent . As an adolescent develops , they seek to understand others and have a better understanding of others . As part of the adolescent ’ s social development , adolescents seek out their friends ’ and family ’ s approval and guidance . As adolescents continue to move through puberty and become more mature , they begin to spend less and less time with their family for more time with their friends . As a result , adolescents ’ friends and people outside their social circle become important influencers in their decision making . As adolescents develop , their self este ems , self - confidenc e , and self image improves as they gain more and more experience within themselves . In the wake of the Coventry Blitz , there was widespread agitation from the Communist Party over the need for bomb-proof shelters . Many Londoners , in particular , took shelter in local church basements and schools . In this instance , many victims turned out to be homeless . The Blitz , however , was a turning point in the development of both underground and underground shel tering . While the government and the civil defense organizations of most Western European nations had tried to convince people to develop underground shelters , their efforts were ineffective . The Blitz helped to shift the people ’ s focus from constructing shelters for their own family members to the development of more centralized shelters that would protect an entire community ’ s hom esteads . As a consequence , the number of shelters constructed in the early months of the war began to decline with less than one- fifth the numbers built in September than were built all of the previous year . Before the early 20th century , treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore . Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over 4 ,0 ,1 thousand years ago by a variety of early cultures , including the Egyptians , the Greeks , and the Romans . As a treatment , these mixtures of various plant and animal ingredients were initially used orally , applied as liniments ( ointments ) and/or applied topically ( rub bed on affected areas of the body . The modern concept of microbes as the cause of infection began in the late 18 th century . In about 17 47 , English researcher Edward Jen ney demonstrated that the pus from boils is transmissible from patients with affected skin ( the skin of patients suffering from bo ils when incised and mixed together ) to other sterile areas of patients without infected skin . Since this initial breakthrough , the concept of infectious disease has dominated much of the medical field over the last 150

Communication within peer groups allows adolescents to explore their feelings and identity as well as develop and evaluate their social skills . Peer groups offer members the opportunity to develop friendship bonds , build self-esteem and identity , develop feelings of inclusion and ultimately promote prosocial behaviour . Moreover , the social context within the peer group also plays a major role in the development of communication . Within peer groups , members develop communication skills in inform al and often less formal situations such as group discussions and debate that require the util iza tion of certain communicative strategies . Communicative processes that take place within peer groups are likely to be influenced and shaped by factors which include the social composition of the group , the nature of the context in which the group meets and how they achieve a sense of unity . Sleep does not affect acquisition or recall while one is awake . Therefore , sleep has the greatest effect on memory consolidation . During sleep , the neural connections in memory are reinfor c ed by the proteins , specifically gamma -aminobuty ric -acid ( GABA ) . GABA is a neuro transmitter , the most abundant neuro transmitter in the brain , which functions to reduce and inhibit the activity of neurons . In hibiting the activity of neurons , GABA leads to the stabilization of long - term memories . In contrast , the same research group also showed that wakefulness impairs memory consolidation . They suggest that learning during the transition between wakefulness and sleep may be the best for memory consolidation ; this may imply that sleeping immediately after learning may be the best for memory consolidation . The vast Seleucid Empire was , like Egypt , mostly dominated by a Greco-Macedonian political elite . The Greek population of the cities who formed the dominant elite were reinforced by a large infl ux of other Greek settlers from Greece and from other provinces and they also controlled almost all army and naval command positions . Although these Maced onians are referred to as members of the Hellenistic states , not all of them were necessarily Hellenized and some were probably still regarded themselves as Maced onians . The native populations were ass imilated to a large degree by the Greek immigrants on the one hand and by the Persian administration and the Greek administration on the other . The Macedonians in Seleuc idia did not all necessarily share the same linguistic and ethnic identity . As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen , potentially damaging ( e.g. , mutation causing ) compounds known as free radicals can form . Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. can gain electrons from compounds with low redox potential ) . They arise when the electron transfer between chemical compounds is imperfect , the unstable intermediates are not completely removed in most chemical reactions . The unpaired electrons of free radicals can react with , damaging components of cell including DNA or cellular organelles ( e.g . , membranes ) or affecting regulation of cell signals . In biology a radical that is oxidized is not a free radical for only two electrons need to be lost . A radical is also not a free radical at the biomole cular level because it could be replaced by one with similar electr o-nuc lease , or it could be a conjug ated compound . The term `` house music '' is said to have originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse , which existed from 1977 to 1983 . Clubbers to The Warehouse would refer to it in conversations and in print as `` house music `` [ what type of music is this ? ] . The club was the forerunner of the global electronic music phenomenon called house . There are also indications that the music called garage music that came out of the Black Sw an in Detroit around 198 5 was directly influenced by The Warehouse . This genre of music gave birth to another genre known as Deep House . Garage /Deep House music is also called J uice music ( from the Black Swan s nickname the J uice Factory ) , as it emerged from the J u ice Factory which operated in conjunction with the club [ what type of music is this ? ] . Since its creation , house music has evol ved into many sub -genres .

In contrast , non- religious Persian mosa ics are mostly of low relief , which were painted on a colored surface which was first co ated with a layer of plaster . By August 1805 , Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally . Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies , he decided to strike first and cut the land communications between Britain and its allies in Europe , thereby severely weakening their potential ability to intervene on the continent . Thus , Napoleon dispatched his Grande Arme to destroy Austrian forces in Italy , forcing them to retreat to Tyrol on their northern border . The invasion of the Tyrol was a tactical success . Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record . It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old , as ev ided by artifacts found in Turkey that date to 5 000 BC . It was first mined in what is now Egypt , along the Nile River , and it was mined by the Celts in Britain . Copper is used for thousands of different purposes and is an important metal both today and in history . In ancient times , it was prized for its use in making jewelry , weapons , and coins . Other ancient peoples such as the Assyrians , Romans , and Egyptians used copper extens i onion rings copper wire . Their usage of copper coincided with the Roman Empire , which is why historians believe that Roman culture helped the Greeks develop a copper mine . Gastrin is released from the stomach to stimulate the secretion of hydrochloric acid and peps in . This phase is actually the period of gastric juice secretion , which occurs 3-5 minutes after the ing es tion of food . The gastr ic phase is the primary site where most digestion occurs . The most effective phase for protein digestion and absorption of nutrients into the bloodstream occurs in the jejunum . The number of species invasions has been on the rise at least since the beginning of the 1900s . Species are increasingly being moved by humans ( on purpose and by accident ) to new biomes and geographical regions . Species invasions are generally bad for the natural environment and also for humans . Some interesting questions arise though : 1 . Are “ native ” or “ natural ” species always “ better ” than “ introduced ” or “ invasive ” ones ? 2 . Is it possible to develop an “ invasion index ” ? How should the criteria of an “ invasive species ” be defined ? What should be included and excluded ? The goal of this investigation is to understand what is meant by biological invasions and to present different models of invasions . These troops were part of Marshall Émile Foch ’ s Central Army , and their successful progress into Russian territory prompted Napoleon to send more of his troops to the region . However , Dum Ourzie z faced fierce resistance from Russian troops at the Battle of K ulikov , where he suffered heavy casualties . This setback triggered a major crisis in Napoleon ’ s plans , as he began to rethink his invasion of south Russia and ultimately ordered a retre ation . In biology , energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism . Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development , the function of its metabolic processes ( homeost asis ) , locomotion , reproduction , the control of behavior , and the maintenance of internal order . In ecology , energy flows through ecosystems , determining the productivity of systems and the health and fertility of their members . Energy is also a factor of the adaptation of organisms to life , through such functions such as the transmission of light or biol uminescence . The transfer of energy through a system is the driving force of its processes by increasing the level of disorder or entropy . Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court , and the monasteries and churches they supported . It was dominated by efforts to regain the traditions of the imperial court of Rome , and was primarily monument al in nature . Many of the Carol ingians were interested in restoring ancient styles , while simultaneously creating a style of their own . Unlike the preceding . the later Merovingian art was not so focused on individual rulers . It was created for a wider number of patrons , who were either inspired by the court - inspired art of the Carolingians or were themselves a part of this period . Since this was not the peak political period of the Caroling ian Empire , and as more of the Carolingians were members of powerful famil ies , rather than direct descendants of Charlemagne , Carol ingian art was produced in a number of regions , as opposed to a single style - defining one particular region for the entire period . The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula throughout Western Europe until the modern period . As Virgil himself claimed in the Prose Editions , the Aeneid was a literary monument and the best poem in Latin , and this opinion was taken as self-evident over many centuries . The Aeneid did not , however , receive the same universal acceptance and admiration as the works of the Greek po ets , most notably Homer , whom Virgil himself cited in the preface ― and Virgil was aware of his debt and indebtedness toward Homer ― even as he himself made no effort to imitate Homer . But Virgil was an extraordinarily influential writer and the A eneid had many and various ― not to say numerous ― admir ators , especially among members of the literary academies of the sixteenth century , the great humanists , and their im itators after them

The list , known as the `` Hit List `` for the first four categories , was completed by April 17 , 1941 . However , many Jews were on it already . On June 1 , 1941 President Franklin D. Roosevelt had his attorney general order the immigration officials to begin rounding up and detaining all persons on the list . The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has always been subject to controversy . Recent commercial developments in animal breeding mean that animals ( or animal components ) are crossed with or genetically manipulated with the intention of producing one or other of an economic , hypoallergen ic or medical end product in mind . Much of this type of breeding is still regulated by the traditional rules surrounding genetic purity and is subject to legislation and animal protection laws . However , the nature of the commercial end product means that animals bred as pure bred animals and allowed to inter breed in order to create a new bre edi ng stock can be subject to genetic manipulation of the animal ’ s genetic make up both prior to their birth and after their birth at a later date . A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment , including Deism and talk of atheism . Deism , according to Thomas Paine , is the simple belief in God without belief in dogma or supernatural occasions . Paine did not believe that science could account for the entire universe . Although he did not know that God created the entire universe in six days , he did believe that God caused the universe . B ecame the most popular religious philosophy between 183 0 and 1 870 . Although it was an agnostic and atheist movement , many people joined in it . The first and most important of the free - thought leaders of this period was the German writer Ludwig Feuerbach . Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Swiss Plateau ( narrowing from a width of about ) in the east to the J ura mountains to the north . The cant on of Geneva lies on the Swiss Pl ateau . The main part of the country lies on the Swiss Plateau , the highest mountain is the Finster aarhorn ( 404 8 m ) , the lowest point is at an altitude of 375 m and at the southern edge of the French Jura . The Rhine Valley lies to the east , and the northern edges of Italy and Austria to the west . In many places on the plateau of the Jura and the Alpine pre- Alps there is a deep gully structure . As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as the legal owner of waqf , was primarily responsible for the distribution of waq ’ fiyya revenues among waqf holders , and that the revenue from non-wa qf property formed part of the wa q ’ f fyya of the madrasa , was accepted in practice ; in the western Islamic world , this practice was at most tolerated . While the religious instruction of the common madr a a was of great importance to many rulers and states men , the teaching of medicine to non - Muslims at the madrasa was not particularly welcomed by most rulers , as the Muslim masses might thus be encouraged to practice medical methods contrary to Islamic law .
